Previous studies have cast some doubt on the differences in signal transduction between monomeric IgE responses and antigen responses; they speculated that monomeric IgE can induce the FcϵRI-aggregation and that a similar signaling pathway is activated upon both responses with different intensities (10Kitaura J. Song J. Tsai M. Asai K. Maeda-Yamamoto M. Mocsai A. Kawakami Y. Liu F-T. Lowell C.A. Barisas B.G. Galli S.J. Kawakami T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 12911-12916Crossref PubMed Scopus (234) Google Scholar, 18Schweitzer-Stenner R. Pecht I. J. Immunol. 2005; 174: 4461-4464Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). Accumulating evidence has indicated that the FcϵRI-mediated activation of mast cells is finely tuned. Gonzalez-Espinosa et al. (23Gonzalez-Espinosa C. Odom S. Olivera A. Hobson J.P. Martinez M.E.C. Oliveira-dos-Santos A. Barra L. Spiegel S. Penninger J.M. Rivera J. J. Exp. Med. 2003; 197: 1453-1465Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar) demonstrated that several chemokines, such as MCP-1, are released at low antigen concentrations or at low receptor occupancy with IgE compared with several cytokines such as IL-3 and IL-10. This result indicated that antigen-induced IL-3 release requires a “strong” stimulation, in which linker for activation of T cells (LAT) and ERK are extensively phosphorylated. On the other hand, Kohno et al. (11Kohno M. Yamasaki S. Tybulewicz V.L.J. Saito T. Blood. 2005; 105: 2059-2065Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar) demonstrated that monomeric IgE-induced survival of BMMCs is mediated by a large amount of IL-3 autocrine production. In this study, IL-3 production by monomeric IgE was found to be much larger than that upon antigen stimulation. Since monomeric IgE was found to elicit a “weak and sustained” signal transduction including ERK phosphorylation (9Kalesnikoff J. Huber M. Lam V. Damen J.E. Zang J. Shiraganian R.P. Krsytal G. Immunity. 2001; 14: 801-811Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (355) Google Scholar), it is likely that IL-3 production by monomeric IgE is regulated by a different mechanism from that upon antigen stimulation. We also found that IL-6 production in MC9 cells stimulated with monomeric IgE was much larger than that upon antigen stimulation under the optimized condition. Our current results clearly demonstrated that PKCβII is a prerequisite component for monomeric IgE-induced activation of mast cells but not for antigen responses. We previously demonstrated that Ca2+ influx induced by monomeric IgE is mediated by channels different from Ca2+ release-activated Ca2+ channel, which is utilized upon antigen responses, using several channel blockers (17Tanaka S. Mikura S. Hashimoto E. Sugimoto Y. Ichikawa A. Eur. J. Immunol. 2005; 35: 460-468Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). We propose that the signaling cascades activated by monomeric IgE are distinguishable from those upon cross-linking of the FcϵRI by multivalent antigen. A mouse mastocytoma cell line, P-815, is a suitable model for the analysis of FcϵRI-mediated activation, since it lacks the surface expression of FcϵRI (19Miller L. Alber G. Varin-Blank N. Ludowyke R. Metzger H. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 21: 12444-12453Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar). We can exhibit the direct evidence of involvement of the FcϵRI in monomeric IgE responses using this cell line, which is consistent with the recent study using BMMCs derived from the FcϵRIα deficient mice (24Kitaura J. Kinoshita T. Matsumoto M. Chung S. Kawakami Y. Leitges M. Wu D. Lowell C.A. Kawakami T. Blood. 2005; 105: 3222-3229Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). Restored Ca2+ influx by PKCβII was observed only in the presence of certain IgE clones and exhibited a similar sensitivity to various kinase inhibitors and channel blockers to that observed in BMMCs (17Tanaka S. Mikura S. Hashimoto E. Sugimoto Y. Ichikawa A. Eur. J. Immunol. 2005; 35: 460-468Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar), indicating that the responses in P-815 cells reproduce those observed in BMMCs. However, no or little induction of HDC and IL-6 was observed upon monomeric IgE treatment or antigen stimulation in P-815 and its transfectants. Since potent activators of mast cells, such as A23187 and thapsigargin, failed to induce histamine synthesis and IL-6 release in P-815 cells (maximum IL-6 release <0.1 pg/ml, data not shown), it is quite difficult to evaluate the effects of IgE-mediated responses. Although detectable levels of IL-6 were found in the concentrated medium of unstimulated P-815 cells, no increase of IL-6 was observed in the presence of A23187. P-815 cells may lack signaling molecules downstream of Ca2+ influx, which are required for detectable levels of induction of HDC and IL-6. The suppressive effects of the mutant PKCβII/T500V on monomeric IgE-induced activation of MC9 cells were consistent with the results obtained in P-815 cells transfected with PKCβII. These suppressive effects were found exclusively in monomeric IgE responses, not in antigen stimulation. Since PKCβI and βII are generated by alternative splicing of the carboxyl-terminal exons and exhibit little differences in enzymatic characters (25Ono Y. Kikkawa U. Ogita K. Fujii T. Kurokawa T. Asaoka Y. Sekiguchi K. Ase K. Igarashi K. Nishizuka Y. Science. 1987; 236: 1116-1120Crossref PubMed Scopus (248) Google Scholar), there have been few studies on the specific roles of each isoform of PKCβII in mast cells. Although previous study using PKCβ deficient mice revealed that BMMC lacking both PKCβI and βII exhibited lower levels of degranulation and IL-6 release than the wild type cells in response to antigen (26Nechushtan H. Leitges M. Cohen C. Kay G. Razin E. Blood. 2000; 95: 1752-1757Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), it remains to be clarified which isoform is responsible for degranulation and IL-6 release. Kawakami et al. (27Kawakami Y. Kitaura J. Hartman S.E. Lowell C.A. Siraganian R.P. Kawakami T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 7423-7428Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 28Kawakami Y. Kitaura J. Yao L. Mchenry R.W. Kawakami Y. Newton A.C. Kang S. Kato R.M. Leitges M. Rawlings D. Kawakami T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 9470-9475Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar) demonstrated that PKCβII was only weakly activated upon the FcϵRI cross-linking compared with PKCβI in BMMCs. Weak activation of PKCβII upon antigen stimulation is consistent with our results that PKCβII did not affect the antigen responses. Very recently, Kawakami et al. (29Kitaura J. Asai K. Maeda-Yamamoto M. Kawakami Y. Kikkawa U. Kawakami T. J. Exp. Med. 2000; 192: 729-739Crossref PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar) demonstrated that PKCβII plays a dominant role in phosphorylation of Akt on Ser473, which contributes to cytokine production, in BMMC upon antigen stimulation (30Kawakami Y. Nishimoto H. Kitaura J. Maeda-Yamamoto M. Kato R.M. Littman D.R. Rawlings D.J. Kawakami T. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 47720-47725Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar). They compared the role of PKCβI and βII retrovirally transduced into BMMC derived from PKCβ-deficient mice. Although antigen-induced histamine release was restored by either of PKCβ isoform, antigen-induced IL-2 release was found to be completely dependent on PKCβII. This result clearly indicated the specific role of PKCβII in the signal transduction downstream of FcϵRI. The PKCβII-Akt pathway may play an important role in monomeric IgE-induced activation of mast cells. It remains unknown how PKCβII is activated by monomeric IgE. Kawakami et al. (28Kawakami Y. Kitaura J. Yao L. Mchenry R.W. Kawakami Y. Newton A.C. Kang S. Kato R.M. Leitges M. Rawlings D. Kawakami T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 9470-9475Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar) demonstrated that 20-70% of PKCβII was localized in the membrane fraction of resting BMMC and only a part of it was tyrosine-phosphorylated upon antigen stimulation. We found that less than 1% of PKCβII is localized in the membrane fraction of MC9 cells and that a minor population of PKCβII was translocated to the membrane fraction by monomeric IgE. Antigen stimulation failed to induce detectable membrane translocation of PKCβII in MC9 cells (data not shown). We prepared another stable MC9 clone, in which an RNA interference sequence for the unique region of PKCβII is retrovirally transduced. Although ∼70% suppression of PKCβII expression on immunoblot analysis was achieved in this clone, no significant suppression was detected in Ca2+ mobilization, histamine synthesis, and IL-6 production, when the cells were stimulated with monomeric IgE (data not shown). These results suggest that a small portion of PKCβII may be able to mediate the monomeric IgE-induced signal transduction. The suppression of monomeric IgE-induced activation by the mutant PKCβII/T500V was found to be significant but partial. However, potency of suppression by each DN clone was correlated with the amount of the unphosphorylated form expressed in each clone. A very low and undetectable level of phosphorylated form of PKCβII may be responsible for the residual HDC and IL-6 expression induced by monomeric IgE in these clones. The region specific for PKCβII contains 52 amino acids and is homologous to the corresponding region of PKCβI. PKCβII was found to bind to RACK1 (the first receptor of activated C kinase) via its C2 domain and carboxyl-terminal specific region (V5 region) with higher affinity than PKCβI (31Stebbins E.G. Mochly-Rosen D. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 29644-29650Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar). Although we could detect the binding of PKCβII to RACK1 in MC9 cells, the amount of bound PKCβII was not changed by monomeric IgE (data not shown). Although specific physiological functions of PKCβII remain to be figured out, several studies have suggested the critical role of PKCβII in vivo. Liu et al. demonstrated that azoxymethane-induced colon carcinogenesis was abolished in PKCβ KO mice and that transduction of PKCβII can restore its susceptibility (32Liu Y. Su W. Thompson E.A. Leitges M. Murray N.R. Fields A.P. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 45556-45563Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). Todt et al. (33Todt J.C. Hu B. Punturieri A. Sonstein J. Polak T. Curtis J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 35906-35914Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar) suggested that PKCβII is involved in phagocytosis of apoptic cells by murine peritoneal macrophages with pharmacological approaches. We revealed in this study that PKCβ isoforms are specifically exploited in the FcϵRI-mediated signal transduction in mast cells. We thank Dr. K.
